brief: All Thrust functionalities related to memory allocation and deallocation.
name: memory_management

publicClasses.brief: device_ptr is a pointer-like object which points to an object that resides in memory associated with the device system.
publicClasses.name: device_ptr
publicClasses.summary: device_ptr is a pointer-like object which points to an object that resides in memory associated with the device system.
publicClasses.title: device_ptr

paramList.name: ptr
paramList.text: The device_ptr to delete, assumed to have been allocated with device_new.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of objects to destroy at ptr. Defaults to 1 similar to device_new.

publicFunctions.details: device_free deallocates memory allocated by the function device_malloc. The following code snippet demonstrates how to use device_free to deallocate memory allocated by device_malloc. ```cpp #include #include ... // allocate some integers with device_malloc const int N = 100; thrust::device_ptr int_array = thrust::device_malloc(N); // manipulate integers ... // deallocate with device_free thrust::device_free(int_array); ```
publicFunctions.name: device_free

paramList.name: ptr
paramList.text: A device_ptr pointing to memory to be deallocated.

publicFunctions.title: device_free

publicFunctions.name: device_malloc

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of bytes to allocate sequentially in device memory.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of objects of type T to allocate sequentially in device memory.

returns: A device_ptr to the newly allocated memory.
A device_ptr to the newly allocated memory.
publicFunctions.title: device_malloc

publicFunctions.details: device_new implements the placement new operator for types resident in device memory. device_new calls T's null constructor on a array of objects in device memory. No memory is allocated by this function.
publicFunctions.name: device_new

paramList.name: p
paramList.text: A device_ptr to a region of device memory into which to construct one or many Ts.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of objects to construct at p.

publicFunctions.title: device_new

publicFunctions.argsString: (device_ptr< void > p, const T &exemplar, const size_t n=1)
publicFunctions.details: device_new implements the placement new operator for types resident in device memory. device_new calls T's copy constructor on a array of objects in device memory. No memory is allocated by this function.
publicFunctions.name: device_new

paramList.name: p
paramList.text: A device_ptr to a region of device memory into which to construct one or many Ts.

paramList.name: exemplar
paramList.text: The value from which to copy.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of objects to construct at p.

publicFunctions.title: device_new

publicFunctions.details: device_new implements the new operator for types resident in device memory. It allocates device memory large enough to hold n new objects of type T.
publicFunctions.name: device_new

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of objects to allocate. Defaults to 1.

returns: A device_ptr to the newly allocated region of device memory.

publicFunctions.name: malloc

paramList.name: system
paramList.text: The Thrust system with which to associate the storage.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of bytes of storage to allocate.

returns: If allocation succeeds, a pointer to the allocated storage; a null pointer otherwise. The pointer must be deallocated with thrust::free.

templateParamsList.name: DerivedPolicy
templateParamsList.text: The name of the derived execution policy.

publicFunctions.title: malloc

publicFunctions.name: malloc

paramList.name: system
paramList.text: The Thrust system with which to associate the storage.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The number of elements of type T which the storage should accomodate.

returns: If allocation succeeds, a pointer to an allocation large enough to accomodate n elements of type T; a null pointer otherwise. The pointer must be deallocated with thrust::free.

templateParamsList.name: DerivedPolicy
templateParamsList.text: The name of the derived execution policy.

publicFunctions.title: malloc

publicFunctions.argsString: (const thrust::detail::execution_policy_base< DerivedPolicy > &system, typename thrust::pointer< T, DerivedPolicy >::difference_type n)
publicFunctions.details: get_temporary_buffer returns a pointer to storage associated with a given Thrust system sufficient to store up to n objects of type T. If not enough storage is available to accomodate n objects, an implementation may return a smaller buffer. The number of objects the returned buffer can accomodate is also returned. Thrust uses get_temporary_buffer internally when allocating temporary storage required by algorithm implementations. The storage allocated with get_temporary_buffer must be returned to the system with return_temporary_buffer. The following code snippet demonstrates how to use get_temporary_buffer to allocate a range of memory to accomodate integers associated with Thrust's device system. ```cpp #include ... // allocate storage for 100 ints with thrust::get_temporary_buffer const int N = 100; typedef thrust::pair< thrust::pointer, std::ptrdiff_t > ptr_and_size_t; thrust::device_system_tag device_sys; ptr_and_size_t ptr_and_size = thrust::get_temporary_buffer(device_sys, N); // manipulate up to 100 ints for(int i = 0; i < ptr_and_size.second; ++i) { *ptr_and_size.first = i; } // deallocate storage with thrust::return_temporary_buffer thrust::return_temporary_buffer(device_sys, ptr_and_size.first); ```
publicFunctions.name: get_temporary_buffer

paramList.name: system
paramList.text: The Thrust system with which to associate the storage.

paramList.name: n
paramList.text: The requested number of objects of type T the storage should accomodate.

returns: A pair p such that p.first is a pointer to the allocated storage and p.second is the number of contiguous objects of type T that the storage can accomodate. If no storage can be allocated, p.first if no storage can be obtained. The storage must be returned to the system using return_temporary_buffer.

templateParamsList.name: DerivedPolicy
templateParamsList.text: The name of the derived execution policy.

publicFunctions.title: get_temporary_buffer
publicFunctions.type: __host__ __device__ thrust::pair< thrust::pointer< T, DerivedPolicy >, typename thrust::pointer< T, DerivedPolicy >::difference_type >
publicFunctions.typePlain: __host__ __device__ thrust::pair< thrust::pointer< T, DerivedPolicy >, typename thrust::pointer< T, DerivedPolicy >::difference_type >

publicFunctions.details: free deallocates the storage previously allocated by thrust::malloc. The following code snippet demonstrates how to use free to deallocate a range of memory previously allocated with thrust::malloc. ```cpp #include ... // allocate storage for 100 ints with thrust::malloc const int N = 100; thrust::device_system_tag device_sys; thrust::pointer ptr = thrust::malloc(device_sys, N); // mainpulate memory ... // deallocate ptr with thrust::free thrust::free(device_sys, ptr); ```
publicFunctions.name: free

paramList.name: system
paramList.text: The Thrust system with which the storage is associated.

paramList.name: ptr
paramList.text: A pointer previously returned by thrust::malloc. If ptr is null, free does nothing.

pre: ptr shall have been returned by a previous call to thrust::malloc(system, n) or thrust::malloc<T>(system, n) for some type T.

templateParamsList.name: DerivedPolicy
templateParamsList.text: The name of the derived execution policy.

publicFunctions.title: free

publicFunctions.argsString: (const thrust::detail::execution_policy_base< DerivedPolicy > &system, Pointer p, std::ptrdiff_t n)
publicFunctions.details: return_temporary_buffer deallocates storage associated with a given Thrust system previously allocated by get_temporary_buffer. Thrust uses return_temporary_buffer internally when deallocating temporary storage required by algorithm implementations. The following code snippet demonstrates how to use return_temporary_buffer to deallocate a range of memory previously allocated by get_temporary_buffer. ```cpp #include ... // allocate storage for 100 ints with thrust::get_temporary_buffer const int N = 100; typedef thrust::pair< thrust::pointer, std::ptrdiff_t > ptr_and_size_t; thrust::device_system_tag device_sys; ptr_and_size_t ptr_and_size = thrust::get_temporary_buffer(device_sys, N); // manipulate up to 100 ints for(int i = 0; i < ptr_and_size.second; ++i) { *ptr_and_size.first = i; } // deallocate storage with thrust::return_temporary_buffer thrust::return_temporary_buffer(device_sys, ptr_and_size.first); ```
publicFunctions.name: return_temporary_buffer

paramList.name: system
paramList.text: The Thrust system with which the storage is associated.

paramList.name: p
paramList.text: A pointer previously returned by thrust::get_temporary_buffer. If ptr is null, return_temporary_buffer does nothing.

pre: p shall have been previously allocated by thrust::get_temporary_buffer.

templateParamsList.name: DerivedPolicy
templateParamsList.text: The name of the derived execution policy.

publicFunctions.title: return_temporary_buffer

publicFunctions.details: raw_pointer_cast creates a "raw" pointer from a pointer-like type, simply returning the wrapped pointer, should it exist.
publicFunctions.name: raw_pointer_cast

paramList.name: ptr
paramList.text: The pointer of interest.

returns: ptr.get(), if the expression is well formed; ptr, otherwise.
publicFunctions.title: raw_pointer_cast

publicFunctions.details: raw_reference_cast creates a "raw" reference from a wrapped reference type, simply returning the underlying reference, should it exist. If the argument is not a reference wrapper, the result is a reference to the argument.
publicFunctions.name: raw_reference_cast
note: There are two versions of raw_reference_cast. One for const references, and one for non-const.

paramList.name: ref
paramList.text: The reference of interest.

publicFunctions.title: raw_reference_cast

publicFunctions.details: raw_reference_cast creates a "raw" reference from a wrapped reference type, simply returning the underlying reference, should it exist. If the argument is not a reference wrapper, the result is a reference to the argument.
publicFunctions.name: raw_reference_cast
note: There are two versions of raw_reference_cast. One for const references, and one for non-const.

paramList.name: ref
paramList.text: The reference of interest.

publicFunctions.title: raw_reference_cast
